document.masterDocTitle: The taxonomy and biogeography of Cuban Ophioninae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The taxonomy and biogeography of Cuban Ophioninae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Ophion thoracicus Cresson, 1865: 55
. Lectotype ♀ , Cuba (PANS), designated by
Gauld, 1988: 272
. [Synoymized by
Townes & Townes, 1966: 177
.]

Ophion trimaculatus Taschenberg, 1875: 433
. Holotype ♀ , Brazil (Halle). [Synoymized by
Townes & Townes, 1966: 177
.]

[
Ophion ( Enicospilus ) concolor Cresson
;
Cameron, 1886: 291
. Misidentification]

Henicospilus trispilus Szépligeti, 1906: 145
. Lectotype ♂ , Venezuela (TM), designated by
Gauld, 1988: 272
. [Synoymized by
Gauld, 1988: 272
.]

Henicospilus attritus Enderlein, 1921: 33
. Holotype ♂ , Peru (IZPAN) [Synonymized by
Gauld, 1988: 272
.]

subSubSection.paragraph:
It is one of the commonest nocturnal ichneumonids in lower montane forest in Central America, and in many sites individuals are extremely abundant, often outnumbering all other species combined ( Gauld, 1988 ). Cuban records include all major regions of the country, from sea level to the highest mountains ( 1874 m .a.s.l.). Two of the specimens I have studied had fore wing length below 15 mm but, apart from that, they closely resembled the Gauld's description of the species, so I am including them as
E. flavoscutellatus
without doubts.
